awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO: Collaborative Research - Human decision-making in complex environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Decision-making is one of the most central cognitive functions of importance at practically all levels of society. In many real-world decisions, which of the available alternatives is chosen is influenced by many different attributes. Such multi-attribute decisions are complex because they require the integration and comparison of many pieces of information. For instance, selecting the bundle of goods that maximizes value given a budget constraint in a supermarket that only stocks 100 different goods requires checking approximately 10^30 possible combinations. For this reason, humans do not use rational choice theory in all their decisions. In addition to having to combine the influence of all the different attributes, another complexity is that one alternative is often preferable on one set of attributes, but another is preferred on others. Making a choice then requires a trade-off, which further complicates the decision process. However, the cognitive and neural processes that are at the heart of preference formation are still poorly understood.  This complexity is thought to tax limited cognitive resources in humans who therefore can pay attention only to a limited set of information, on which the decision is then based. In addition, task history often systematically changes decision biases. This research program takes advantage of the opportunity to obtain direct recordings from individual's brains while they perform such complex decision. It will study these activity patterns to determine whether they can be explained via mathematical models of decision making. Understanding which attributes are considered during decision making, and how they are weighted could explain decision making in typical and a-typical populations. Furthermore this integrative research program forms an opportunity to expose engineering students to dynamical systems and control theories in an interdisciplinary context.

This project combines behavioral data, neural recordings in humans (patients undergoing epilepsy evaluation) implanted with multiple depth electrodes covering many cortical and subcortical brain areas, and computational approaches to develop a new theory of the neural mechanisms underlying multi-attribute decision-making in complex environments. This is a unique opportunity to study brain circuits simultaneously across multiple brain areas while humans make these decisions.  The overall goal of the present proposal is to understand the neural circuit involved in (1) representing the relevant decision variables, (2) integrating these variables to form subjective values, and (3) selecting one of the options in multi-attribute decisions. Participants, with implanted electrodes, will work in a novel behavioral task that makes it possible to observe their focus of attention while they evaluate the offers and select one of them.  Data will constrain cutting edge computational models of multi-attribute decision making that will combine: (i) a procedural model of the decision in each trial, and (ii) a latent variable model of biasing influence on decision-making resulting from past trial history. The computational models will make it possible to identify neuronal activity that represents task-relevant variables and the dynamic flow of information across the different elements of the identified neural circuit.

por.por_cntn:
During this project, we simultaneously recorded behavioral and neural data from patients with implanted depth electrodes - stereoelectroencephalogram (sEEG) electrodes using our tablet-based multi-attribute decision making task. Data collection is ongoing at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center (UPMC). To date, neural and behavioral data have been collected from 19 patients. Neural data was collected in the form of stereoelectroencephalogram (sEEG) recordings (LFTS)  from subjects who were receiving treatment for medically intractable focal epilepsy. Subjects were implanted with electrodes according to their clinical care plan and then placed under observation until sufficient seizure data are obtained to develop a plan for surgical intervention. 

In a iPAD task during their epilepsy monitoring unit stay, each decision making option presents the subject with a possibility of winning or losing virtual money (neutral outcomes are also possible). The four possible attributes are win amount, win probability, loss amount, and loss probability. On a given trial, only winning or losing options are presented. The gambles appear as gray bars with red and green symbols. When they touch the symbols, the symbols disappear and reveal either the amount they can receive (under the green dollar sign), the probability of getting that amount (under the green dice), or the amount participants can lose (under the red dollar sign) or the probability that they will lose that amount (under the red dice). On a given trial, only either winning or losing options were presented. Participants can either lose, win, or neither. They can look back at each gamble as many times as they want, by tapping on its red or green symbols. Once they have decided which of the gambles they want to bet on, they tap its ?select? button. All properties of their chosen gamble (amounts and probabilities) were briefly displayed, and after that, the screen showed how much virtual money they have won or lost in this round.

Behavioral data from the tablet was synchronized with the clinical neurophysiological recording system via a custom-built device that communicates with the tablet via Bluetooth and sends behavioral event codes and timestamps to the clinical system. This allows for maintained synchronization of the data throughout the task and analysis of sEEG signals associated with key behavioral events.

In order to identify any time-frequency regions in the task-aligned spectrograms that differ significantly in spectral power between the compared task conditions, we used a nonparametric cluster-based test [Maris and Oostenveld, 2007]. Here, all time-frequency regions that show no significant difference (p > 0.05) between win and loss trials were masked (white). Regions with significantly greater power on win trials were noted and further analyzed.  For some individuals, the medial frontal gyrus, wins result in significantly more power in lower frequencies (below 40 Hz). Spectral analysis of the event-aligned sEEG recordings were being used to broadly summarize neural activity during the task and to identify locations in the brain that seem to be significantly related to key elements of the task.

Another line of analysis conducted in parallel is focused on cross-frequency modulation. Specifically, we looked for phase-amplitude modulation. Phase-amplitude modulation has been observed both in animals and humans across a variety of experimental conditions [Cohen et al., 2008, Canolty et al., 2006, Canolty and Knight, 2010]. A band-pass filter was applied to the sEEG data to extract the gamma and theta band signals. The theta frequency band was defined as 4?8 HZ and the gamma band was defined as 40?200 HZ. To determine the level of modulation of the amplitude of the gamma waves by the phase of theta, the theta phase was sorted in to bins and gamma amplitude was averaged in each bin. A first-order sinusoid was then fit to the gamma amplitude as a function of theta phase. The amplitude and phase of the fit sinusoid as well as the least-squares error were extracted as metrics of the phase-amplitude modulation. Significance of the modulation relationship was asses via permutation test.

Results showed significant theta-gamma phase-amplitude modulation in the time period aligned to feedback, separated by whether the outcome of the trial was positive (win or avoid loss) or negative (lose or fail to win). Importantly, several recordings from the orbitofrontal cortex showed significant phase-amplitude modulation only following positive outcomes, but not following negative outcomes. A manuscript submission is in porgress and ready for submission shortly.
